title: 110_hr4218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with millions affected and increasing prevalence. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to effectively manage their condition, provided by certified diabetes educators. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified diabetes educators, helps individuals effectively manage their condition and reduce risks. Lifestyle changes have been shown to significantly decrease the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, especially in older individuals. Lifestyle changes, including those taught by certified diabetes educators, can reduce the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by 58%. These changes are particularly effective in individuals aged 60 and older, with a 71% reduction in diabetes development. Studies show that patients under the care of certified diabetes educators have better glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes. Proper medical treatment and active self-management can prevent serious complications of diabetes by up to 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke. There are over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US, most certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certification requires specific healthcare credentials, experience in diabetes self-management, passing a national exam, and periodic credential renewal. Certified educators are qualified to provide diabetes self-management training under Medicare. Certified diabetes educators are recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are licensed health care professionals specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certified diabetes educators must be certified by a recognized certifying body, like the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, or a body authorized by the Secretary. The certifying body must meet specific requirements for certification. Certified diabetes educators in the United States must meet specific requirements for certification, including having a qualifying credential, professional practice experience, passing a national certification examination, and renewing certification periodically. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for effective outreach methods to educate primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will submit a report to Congress on recommendations for outreach methods to promote diabetes self-management training benefits. The amendments will apply to diabetes outpatient self-management training services after six months from the enactment of the Act.
